bibl.title: Letter, C.A. Eames in Millwood, Tenn. to O.P. Temple in Knoxville, Tenn., 1861 December 12
bibl.note: In this letter, dated December 12, 1861, C.A. Eames in Millwood, Tenn. writes to O.P. Temple in Knoxville, Tenn. about the case of John McMackin, for which Eames is to be a witness. He inquires whether he might send his "contracts" instead of coming in person as he fears that, "being a Northern Man," he will be arrested.

projectDesc.p: Machine-readable transcription created for the University of Tennessee Libraries Special Collections.

div.p: Office of C.A. Eames' Boot and Shoe Manufactory,
Millwood, Washington County, East Tenn., Dec 12 1861

Mr John McMackin tells me that you are to assist him in his case & desire me to appear as a Witness in his behalf I only wish to inquire if I send you my contracts between myself & the parties I bot hoggs for if it will not do as well as for me to come in person as I am a man that they have had a great desire to arrist being a Northern Man & I wish to conduct myself in such a ways as not to give them a cause to malest me at all as my presents in my Business at home call so Strong. McMackin was Buying hogs for me & the Bonds I have will prove that the hogs was Bot for the Southern Government so I think McMackin clear of the charge made against him.
Write me at once at Millwood PO/ I dont want to come to Knox
